The failure of the older golf ball is not necessarily all due to differences in the construction. Material/molecular breakdown plays a large role. Until an accurate amount of molecular deterioration can be established, using the older golf ball as a test model, can not provide accurate results. Then, shooting a golf ball weighing 1.6 ounces at 500 MPH is going to produce just under 11,000 foot pounds of energy, and when the target weighs about 0.900 pounds motionless, is there really any question to the end result?

The old ball vs the newer ball was not an equal comparison. The color of the number on the balls has a meaning. Black is harder than red and therefore your elastic curves are not the same. 80 compression, 90 compression, 100 compression. The compression metric affects the balls performance in relation to softer strokes compared to harder strokes ie lower compression balls are more controllable during puts but higher compression balls are longer flight for driving. On that stress-strain curve example with the paperclip, the elastic portion of the curve should be linear. In the elastic domain, stress and strain (deformation) are linearly dependant. The slope of the stress stain curve in the elastic domain is what's know as Young's Modulus (E). Also, as you venture into the plastic domain, when you remove the force (or stress), it does not follow the plastic curve back to zero as you show in your animation. At the point where the stress is removed, the you draw a line that has the same slope as the elastic portion of the curve (equal to E). At zero force (or stress) this straight line will intersect at a given strain (or deformation) which is equal to the permanent set. Because the part is deformed plastically, it does not go back to zero deformation.

For such smart guys, they certainly don't seem capable of very basic back-of-a-napkin energy calculations. So, you're going to fire a golf ball at 500 mph. That's 733 feet per second. A typical .45 ACP bullet has a muzzle velocity of only 800-1000 feet per second. A typical .45 ACP bullet weighs around 230 grains (0.526 ounces). A regulation golf ball is 708 grains (1.62 ounces).

So, you're going to fire a projectile (which may have a catastrophic material failure that causes it to shatter into shards), that weighs over three times as much as a large pistol bullet, at speeds VERY close to that of a pistol bullet, INDOORS, with only a blanket or tarp as a "safety backstop" to keep if from going through the wall if it misses or glances off the target?

That is incredibly stupid. If you had even done the most basic of energy calculations, you would have done this on a proper shooting range setup. At least, if you had a lick of common sense.

Of course it went through a watermelon. And of course it had enough energy left to perforate the blanket and tarp behind it. It was literally more energetic than a pistol bullet.

Normal people buy golf clubs to play golf.

These guy buy them to destroy them with 500 mph golf balls.

It's a pity that it wasn't the same speed rating on both golf balls, as evidenced by the red number versus the black number on the old and new balls, respectively. The red number is what is known as a 90-compression structure, meaning that it reaches optimal compression and energy transfer at 90mph. The black number indicates a 100-compression structure, meaning - you guessed it - that it reaches optimal compression and energy transfer at 100mph.

Granted, the disintegration of the older ball could have numerous variables contributing to the deconstitution of the cover and internal banding, including oxidation of the cover, long-term distress from use, element exposure, repeated compression, as well as the difference due to improvements in the ballistic and elastic technology made in the intervening years since the older ball's design. Even in a sealed interior, that rubber has a tendency to break down once oxidation sets in on the cover, yellowing it. We used to use hook-bladed razors to cut open older balls versus newer balls.

I wonder when they stopped using elastic bands inside the balls?

Back in the early 1970's I was given permission to collect golf balls from the back of a range in an area that was cost prohibitive to collect the balls (it was very rough terrain - swampy Canadian shield rock... and we were a couple of young kids so the 10 cents per hour profit we made selling the balls was worth it to us...). Interested in seeing what was inside I cut open many of the slightly damaged or scuffed balls and discovered that all of the real golf balls were essentially balls of wrapped up elastic bands with a plastic cover with dimples in it. The practice balls had a sort of foamy interior (like an expanding foam sealant). There were also a bunch of really old balls that didn't have dimples that we assumed were old, cheap practice balls from the 1050's.

It looks like the earlier rocket powered golf club did not have enough collective mass to maintain inertia when it hit the ball. Without human arms holding the club, it's so light weight that it has surprisingly little energy to impart onto the golf ball and that energy is practically exhausted the moment it makes contact with the ball.
That seems to be why the "average human" swing maintains contact between ball and club for longer, while the "rocket swing" not only maintains that contact for just an instant, but also has the club bounce backwards on contact.

The most amazing thing to me was the elastic property of the outside of the golf ball. The materials in the old golf ball had aged and become MUCH less elastic. It is probably less about the construction, and more about the simple age of the materials. The driver head failure doesn't surprise me at all. I caved in and cracked a number of the early metal driver heads, just swinging them manually. The newer driver heads are considerably stronger (for a while they made some with Kevlar), but 500 mph is so far beyond what a human can produce, it really couldn't go any other way.


It's probably worth mentioning that when a good golfer swings a driver, the shaft is actually flexed forward by the moment of impact. That may not make sense until you study the mechanics of a human golf swing, but it is true. The forward flex of the shaft is ready made to absorb a portion of the impact of collision, so the club head isn't taking it all.

hey question regarding the club placement.... I'm not an engineer but to keep true to the realities of golf, I don't think the golf club should have been fixed rigidly to the board. Having the club fixed like that forced the club face to absorb wayyyy more energy than it would even a swing at the same speed. While I understand that is 100% the point of the test, it's not accurate to the physics of a golf club hitting a golf ball. i think the club should have been allowed to pivot at the top and kinda get flung back after the golf ball hits it. I am not saying i'm correct but I think it's understating the strength of the club face.

I shot a golf ball 4.2 miles. I covered the ball in high impact golf club epoxy.  Barrel i used was a piece of 12ft pipe lined with chrome . Combustion chamber was a 2in. salute cannon with 4oz of fffg black powder with a taper bore 12in long. Bore is tapered from 2.0 -2.1 at the bottom. Hammer packed news paper and foil  creates the frictionizing combustion point and i see a 30% increase in pressue using the taper bore theory of the wadding once packed at 2.1 I.D. then having to squeeze out a 2.0 I.D.  increases the pressure vs a standard bore. A suggestion for higher velocity. Like Myth Busters supersonic ping pong ball, the vacuum is critical to high velocity. This vacuum is slowly destroyed by leakage around the ball (in video, tape bulges out before the ball strikes it) and this leakage limits the benefits of using a longer barrel for higher speed. I suggest using a longer barrel with a cross fitting at the muzzle end and vacuum storage chambers connected to the sides of the cross. The chambers would keep the pressure at the end of the barrel lower, even with more leakage around the ball.

Seeing the watermelon shot, it got me thinking about other things I have seen that turned a watermelon into....mist.

Thus, I had to figure out the "muzzle energy" of this damned golfball.

So, a golfball, has an upper "tournament legal" limit of 45.93 grams. However.....that's not very accurate, so I found a thread where someone weighed 12 golfballs from Titleist, where their average weight was 45.64 grams. Conveniently, it appears as though Destin and Mark are using Titleist balls.

So, using the standard energy calculation of E=MV^2, (Okay, I used a ballistic calculator cause I am lazy!)

At 300 MPH (440 fps), this yields 303 ft-lbs of energy.
At 400 MPH (586.7 fps), this yields 538 ft-lbs of energy.
At 500 MPH (733.3 fps), this yields 841 ft-lbs of energy.
At 550 MPH ( 806.7 fps), this yields 1018 ft-lbs of energy.

Bloody golfballs!

The experiment pertaining to the golf club proved nearly nothing. You put the anvil behind the direct impact point, rather than better securing the handle, which does not most properly demonstrate what you were trying to figure out, although even if you did do this, you would still get inaccurate results considering you’re moving the ball towards the club, rather than club towards the ball, where the source of power is being derived from the handle at the top, and as a result the experiment doesn’t take into account the centrifugal force and directional momentum, since the club is also much heavier and denser than the ball.

You should try different gases in your cannon. The maximum velocity you can achieve in theory is equal to the speed of sound in that gas. For air that's 343 m/s. This was all interesting and fun to watch. However, in normal usage neither the club or the ball are in a static position and having to absorb the energy involved in the action. That has to make a difference in the way the energy is dealt with by the objects. In your tests you have the energy in the ball hitting the club held still, while in real life the club hits the ball and starts pushing the ball away from its stationary position while the elastic deformation occurs so the force is still being applied to the ball while the elastic collision is still happening. That means a difference in performance characteristics to your test environment. What would be interesting is to see how things go if you can devise a machine to swing a driver at 500 mph to hit the ball and to see how the results differ.

A collision in which deformation occurs - even if the deformation is not permanent - is called an INELASTIC collision. This is because some of the initial kinetic energy is converted to heat via the deformation (again, this is true even if the deformation is only temporary).

For example, this is why steel ball bearings bounce higher than rubber balls when dropped from the same height onto a steel plate.

Asked Mythbusters the same regarding their ping pong vacuum gun: Why don't you add a tank on the exit end of the pipe. Connected with small slots before the tape. Experimenting based on the golf club hitting the ball (experiment type 1) and the ball hitting the golf club (experiment type 2) is not the same in order to determine golf club swing velocity necessary to deform the ball. If it were to just find the threshold at which the ball will deform, you can use a pressure crusher.

The golf ball being lighter in weight will absorb much lesser overall energy (due to its elastic nature) before being propelled. In other words, the golf club would need to use much more energy in experiment type 1 than the energy used to propel the ball in experiment type 2.

What type of driver was used?  Steel or titanium?  Also, why not test with a drop-forged 2 or 3 iron that would have more strenth and ductility?  You guys needed someone with knowledge about golf equipment!  That test with the 1960 ball was a goof!  Golf balls of the 1960s era were made of non-polymeric synthetic rubber compound (as apposed to modern balls made primarily of a polybutadiene petroleum-based polymer), which means the that 1962 ball had deteriorated significantly over time and was already compromised.  So while it was fun destroying it proved nothing.   Besides, the more burning question (at least for us golfers) is, how far can a modern golf ball actually travel before reaching its elastic limit?"  Or to put it another way, how far would a ball travel if struck by Thor or The Hulk?

I am sure many of you have seen cracked golf balls, It is my understanding with those often it is the result of the ball being 1 very old, 2 having gotten very hot, or 3 having gotten very cold. Age and temperature can cause the inner cores or outer shell to loose some of their elastic properties, then the crack often actually happens when the then compromised ball is hit with a bad strike from an Iron. In a bad strike the force of the strike can be concentrated on an edge of the iron meaning that while there may actually be less overall force transferred to the ball, there can be more force transferred in a confined area like the edge of an iron (e.g. less force but more force per inch of contact) this can be sufficient to make a ball appear as if it was cut (typically its the outer shell that becomes compromised). I am no scientist but I live in Texas were people like to leave stuff in their car, and many golfing friends have told me that this is what they feel is the reasoning.

Seeing that golf ball hit and damage the golf club reminded me of the videos I've seen of the Chicken Gun the USAF uses to see what damage birds can do to aircraft parts and canopies. The Chicken Gun fires raw chickens of several caliber sizes. There have been several aircraft manufacturing facilities that have built chicken guns to test the effects of bird strikes on various aircraft parts/structures, canopies and jet engines. It is amazing the damage even a small bird can do to aircraft flying at high speed.

As for the golf ball hitting the club, I hope you guys achieve one hitting hard enough to lodge inside the club. It would make an assume trophy!
On another note,

I was surprised at the older golf ball. I remember as a kid we would cut them apart to see what was inside. In some of the early golf balls inside all that rubber band stuff, was a smaller rubber ball. The old ones were filled with a liquid (Liquid Cores) that was hazardous and were manufactured in to the 1980's. I remember hearing reports of kids dissecting liquid core golf balls that exploded causing injuries because of some crystals that formed in that liquid, also well in to the 80's. The crystals would cause the explosion when crushed. That can also happen today with some PVC glue primers, the purple stuff. It can form crystals in the threaded area of the cap and go off when the cap is unscrewed.

That old golf ball with rubber bands has likely lost some elasticity over time. Not sure it could endure it even new, but something to consider.

In the video with the Wilson Ultra club, that's a mostly aluminum cast body (an alloy with maybe 1% or less titanium at best). The previous looked like a better club, but hard to tell. It would've been good to use something of higher caliber (titanium build) for the test.

The face of the club is much thicker than the body (has to be). The body is much thinner, but like an eggshell, having enough strength to withstand the direction of force along the length. If you hit the top of the club it would dent easily by an average golf swing.

Also to show the difference between the elastic ball and something like a rock or concrete, smack a club against the ground and see how easy it dents or breaks.

Seeing that 1960s vintage ball reminds me that, as a kid back in the 60s, I once tried dissecting a golf ball. I sawed through the outer shell, and as soon as I cut into the tightly-wound rubber band-like interior, it unravelled with great force, and then the liquid core (which I hadn't known about) EXPLODED all over the place! Like an idiot, I had done this indoors, and I had to hurriedly clean grey goo off of everywhere (including the ceiling) before my parents got home. I believe modern golf balls are no longer constructed that way, so inquisitive kids today won't get a similar shock.

Very nice video, but one thing bothered me at the beginning: The elastic region in your stress-strain curves is not linear and that was inflicting with my knowledge of Hooke's law.
Then I dug deeper and learned that many polymers (which most likely all golf balls are made of) have a non-linear elastic response.
As a material scientist who works most with metals and semiconductor this was something I didn't see before.
Thanks for this opportunity to learn something new.
One of my professors in college made a machine to measure elasticity of golf balls for R&D and production of golf ball cores.

The speed limit of a gun is the sound speed in the working fluid.  Since you're using air at room temperature, you're never going to get up to, let alone beyond, about 750 mph. In fact, you're getting about 500 mph, which is decently close to the limit.  However, the sound speed of helium and, much more dangerously, hydrogen, is much higher, nearly a mile per second for hydrogen.  Helium's sound speed isn't quite as fast, but lacks any explosion risk.  Please try it again with helium.

According to me,
When you are hitting a ball with somthing, there are 2 things happen.
1) its absorb the energy from the driver
2)it will start moving forward, because there is nothing in the front of the ball other the air. So some energy will start to convert into velocity immediately.

This conversion will not happen if you throw a ball toward something.
The ball have to absorb all the energy at a time.


So the conclusions is
Because of the absence of the conversion into velocity, the awesome spot or plastic deformation of a throwing ball to a object will be less then a ball hit by a club(driver)

It also occurred to me that a driver moving at 500mph will react to hitting a stationary golf ball differently than a golf ball going 500mph will react to a stationary driver head. The reason the golf club failed so catastrophically compared to the golf ball is because it is designed to be a very stiff material in order to transfer the force of the swing onto the golf ball. Being such a stiff material, it has very little give before it fails, whereas the golf ball can withstand that amount energy transfer in elastic potential energy and convert it into kinetic energy as it leaves the golf club.

Since you mentioned material science and showed the concept of Force-Displacement (Stress-Strain) curve, it's worth saying that at that speed an important role is played by the high rate of strain, which makes the elastic curve way steeper, or in other terms the materials behave as stiffer. Hence the force required to enter the plastic regime is higher than in the case of applying the same deformation slower.

I feel the need to say Mythbusters did a project similar to this and found they could increase the speed vastly by increasing the length of the barrel (and size of the pressurized tank) But ran into a problem that air was able to travel aroung their ball (a ping pong ball) and slow it down by cushioning the collision with the tape at the muzzle. One could easily solve this problem by adding a reservoir of vacuum near the end. What I mean by that is adding a small pipe (Or a few on each side) Leading out of the side of the barrel near the pipe to a container of some sort (It doesn't need to be large, but as your barrel length increases, so should the size of the area for this) to allow the air in front of the ball to evacuate and make way for the ball itself. This would remove the pressure reversal as the ball reaches the end of the barrel, and increase the ball's speed.

With a really good video camera, or even a really good still camera...

There are sensors that can be "added: to a golf ball - but would also make it illegal for regulated play. The sensors would still remain intact in a 500+ collision speed.

There are other ways of tracking trajectory... Marking the ball in a certain way and then using a professional still camera - one could track the trajectory, even beyond one mile. The better the still camera frame rate would be the better the results, but would also need to be a minimum of 6fps. To ensure proper results, the shutter speed would also need to remain above 1/2000th of one second.

Then there's software based tracking using almost any off the shelf dslr starting at about four hundred. This is basically what "golf television: does. Although this is limited to "real golf" speeds and also generally limited to about 500-600 yards.

Love a bit of materials science making it into your channel. One cool thing about plastic verses elastic deformation is because elastic deformation is literally the compression of interatomic bonds, even if a material is plastically deformed (which usually is via in some form of atomic rearrangement) the elastic part is always recoverable. So your final amount of deformation will be the total plastic deformation, minus the plastic deformation. It's interesting because I would imagine at these high speeds the shear rate - not just deformation, but rate of deformation change, is likely to play a part, which means at these high speeds the materials science needed is that of viscous liquids.

You mentioned that the ball got hot from the deformation; it looks like the heat gain in the old ball may significantly contribute to the destruction of the outer layer in partially melting the plastic. We did exactly that topic on elasticity in PCVU (= Physikalosche Chemie, Verfahrens und Umwelttechnik) (physical chemistry, production and surroundings technology, or something likr that) in school. And yes, this is a real school subject in Austria.

What's with vacuum cannons? Positive pressure is thousands of times better than vacuum. Literally, using a positive 1 atm cannon is the same as using a "perfect" vacumm cannon (you will NEVER reach full vacuum) with a bicycle handpump you can easily reach 12 atm, with a good compressor, 30 atm and with an hpa (high-pressure air) pump or compressor, 200 atm.
Why are people insisting on using such an inefficient method?

This is probably mentioned a million times in the comments, but just in case... my understanding of the elastic deformation (hooke’s law) part of a material’s stress/strain curve is a linear relationship, i.e. a straight line. The ‘curve’ only starts to deviate from that when it reaches its yield strength and starts plastically deforming. So either my understanding is inaccurate, or your graphic explaining the deformation of a material under varying load is slightly misleading. Perhaps I’m being pedantic, but I guess that’s what engineers do 🤷🏻‍♂️ please clarify. Thanks.

I feel like boring so I did a math.
Let's see how fast watermelon debris traveling at the moment golf ball hit watermelon.

The goofball hit watermelon at exactly at 21.532 ms and if you pause immediately at 21.639 the debris particles is at 1.5 times the diameter of goofball from the goofball.
Now goofball diameter is 42.67mm. So it travels 64mm in 107 micro seconds. 59.8mm in 100 micro seconds for easy math.
598 meters in one second. I.e 2152 kilometres or 1337 miles in an hour.

A couple of things.

PGA recognizes the nature of the elastic strain curve for golf balls and driver faces. With the advent of more physically fit golfers and high compression golf balls, many drivers are out driving the designs of the courses. Their solution is to limit the spring factor on the driver face (about 10 years ago).

Driver manufacturers are developing ways to get around this. Fluid damaging on over sprung faces, harmonic dampened sweet spots, etc.

There is also a movement among pros who feel the balls need to be softened to take the game back to the glory days of the 60’s and 70’s.

You have the failure point at the end. Actually, the failure point is at the point where elastic deformation becomes plastic deformation.
If you have a structural component and it has gone past the transition point, it might look normal, but it is, in fact, already failed.
An airplane taking off out of Daytona Beach airport (A Piper) had a failed wing spar. The spar looked perfectly normal, but when a load was applied the wing separated and the plane crashed.

I know Im too late for you to see this, but Im an MSE student and I have a cool point about plastic deformation. Usually the slope of elastic deformation is linear. If you apply force to the object to the point of plastic deformation and you redraw the slope of plastic deformation to the point you reached in plastic, you will then have a difference in strain on your x-axis. That is the amount the object has deformed. It easily represents why you have to bend a paperclip past the point you want it at. To simplify even though the material reaches a point of plastic deformation, when the force is removed the material must fall back through its elastic deformation.

I hope this makes sense, its kinda hard to describe it without a stress strain curve.

Hey Destin. I just wanted to point something out and ask if you know an answer to my problem as well. I'm not particularly studying material science but we had a course what gave an overview of it and there they taught us that if the material is in the elastic zone it is close to Hooke's Law (straight line) and when you go to plastic zone then its curved (quite the same way you showed). The thing what confused me wasn't exactly the linear relation but rather that you showed on the graph that if you go to plastic region and let go the force-distance line stays the same but we were taught that if you let go from the plastic region you have to go back on a straight line (Hooke's Law) with the same angle as if it was when you deformed it. But as you start going back on a straight line right away, you end up a little right on your distance line (when force is 0) and this is what describes the actual plastic deformation what we can see when no force is deforming material (the paperclip stays in a different position or the golf ball gets a new shape). But how would this logic be carried out in such an example where we can't express elastic region as linear equation between force and distance, as you showed. Do we actually know what type of equation describes the elastic bending? How will it work out if the point of going back happens to be higher than the elastic region reaches? Maybe you are more familiar with this kind of graphing and math with pressure tests. Cool vid tho ;) (Y)

I like to think about it in terms of two related oversimplified ways.

A golf ball breaks when it cannot respond quickly enough to a fast change. Then, you can compare two velocities: the sound velocity of waves in the golf ball and the velocity of something hitting the golf ball or vice versa the golf ball hitting something. When a golf ball bounces, you can see that the sound wave looks much faster than the ball and it quickly bounces off.

Turns out that the speed of sound in a solid is related to "Young's Modulus" which relates forces and deformation. One oversimplified way to think about Young's Modulus is the energy per volume holding something together: each volume of stuff has a number of atoms, and each atom is bound to other atoms, and each atomic bond has some amount of energy ~ electron volt (eV). If you put enough energy into a small region of golf ball so that the energy per atom is high enough to break the bonds, the golf ball breaks. I think there is some focusing of energy into a small part of the ball. Atomic bond energy per volume is also related to heat capacity and this is also why the golf ball gets hot (and related to why hot things melt).

If you type "(1 eV / proton mass)*gram* cm^-3" into Google you'll find this equals Gigapascals. That's because order of magnitude each atomic bond ~ 1 eV of energy, 1 gram/proton mass / cm^3 is very very roughly # of atoms per cubic centimeter. In reality objects have young moduli that range from 0.001 to 1000 GPa: many kinds of atoms, atomic bonds/structures, and densities.
